p.s: In his speech, Michel Barnier talks about the consequences of the Brexit for the open singelsingle market of the EU.
Moreover he uses a special structure and choice of words as well as some stylistic divicesdevices, to have an impact of his listenerslisteners' and readersreaders' opinion of the topic.
He starts the line of argumentation with pointing out his own opinion on the topic (cf. ll. 1f.).
After that he mentions that Brexit will necessarilly have a cost (ll. 2f.).
Following to that he explains what he means with cost by stating that Brexit will impact a lot of value chains (cf. ll. 4f.) and will lead to big problems in some economical sectors (cf. ll. 8f.).
Ongoing he says that a no deal scenario which he titeltitles as worst case scenario (ll. 13f.) would lead to a [...] return of tariffs under WTO rules (l. 14).
This, he says, would even impact US subsidiaryssubsidiaries.
After that he comes to tearmsterms with keeping a close relationship with the Brexit, to prevent this economical troubelstroubles (cf. l. 15).
He states, that it would be in a common interest (l. 16) to achieve this.
He says that a remaining of an open single market and capital movement (cf. l. 18) would be two possible ways.
He also states that a Free Trade Agreement with the Brexit would guarantee that (cf. l. 20).
To end his list of ideas to keep a good relationship, he says that the European equivalence system also works for the Brexit (cf. ll. 20ff.).
But in the end of his speech he clearly points out that the EU will remain the most open market in the world (l. 28).
And that US comanies are used to this and even achieved to take leading roles in the EU market (cf. ll. 30f.).
He then ends his speech by think his audience.

What belongs to the stylistic divicesdevices and his choice of words, it is obvious to see that he often uses the personal pronouns I or my in combination with a verb like conviction or think to express his thoughts, but then uses the pronoun we to catch his audience and put them into his planesplans (e.g. l. 1, l. 15) with this construction of words he catches the ation of the audience by saying that he (the narrator) and the listeners should do something as a group.
He expressexpresses that he can't change anything without the support of the audience.
But it is important to say that he mensmeans the europeanEuropean people when he says we and not his americanAmerican actuellactual audience.
Furthermore he uses the word channel in l. 11 in a metephortialmetaphorical way to connect the real physical boarderborder of the EU and the UK with the political boarderborder.
By doing that he expresses that the boardersborders or the diffrencesdifferences of bosthboth unions ain't that big.
Other thenthan this he uses an alliteration in l. 25 with which works well.
By saying that he makemakes his speech sound more rytmicalrhythmical and he highlights the fact that the equivalence system works good.
One line after this he uses a rhetorical question with [...] not work for the UK?.
In this way he made his listeners thinking about his idea just by asking them to find out why his idea would not work.
He even creatscreates ana dramatic effect by saying right after Why? (l. 26), which gives his rhetorical question more power.
Last but not least he creatscreates an enumeration in l. 27 [...] more open, comprehensive and rule-based [...].
By listing thisthese aspects of the European jurisdiction he showshows this in a positivpositive light and also statestates that the europeanEuropean one is the best one in the world.
In conlusionconclusion he structured his speech on purpose by listing some consequences of the Brexit first and then saying how to prevent them.
Moreover he uses a couple of stylistic devices to express how good the europeanEuropean system works and to make his speech more intrestinginteresting and interactive for his audience.
